Society will judge people for not wanting to have kids but honestly what's 
worse, a person who chooses to not have children or a person who has 
children and doesn't want them?  Imagine all the psychological issues that 
would arise if your parents didn't want you to exist.﻿

comments.text:
+TheYasmineFlower Well the woman is entitled to feel hatred towards her 
child. That's not even the issue. What she cannot do is express those 
emotions to that child, as she has a responsibility to care for and support 
them. I'm not arguing that she has a responsibility to feel a certain way, 
but rather a responsibility to control her emotions and her behaviour in 
the presence of her child.

comments.text:

carry it out. Just because you get a tumor doesn't mean you have to leave 
it inside of you. And cancer cells are hardly non-life, now aren't they?
comments.author: TheYasmineFlower

comments.text:

one's fault - except the fault of the sperm, maybe.
comments.author: TheYasmineFlower

comments.text: +HorseGirlb blank Dude, don't feed the troll.
comments.author: kisamehoshigaki09

comments.text:
+Battenburg70 There's nothing to reply to. You basically tried to insult my 
argument, without acknowledging or responding to any of it.

Your position is that we should take the rights of pregnant women and *not* 
men who have unprotected sex and *women who have unprotected sex and 
randomly happen to not get pregnant.* I just learned the term *pregnancy 
discrimination* the other day and it fits here beautifully. Simply being 
pregnant does not make you less of a human being.

But again. You gave no reasons for why I might be wrong, you just whined 
"that doesn't make sense!" and threw a short tantrum. Unfortunately, you 
seem to care more about being right than the lives of people affected by 
this issue. That is, again, something I would describe as immature and 
childish.
comments.author: HorseGirlb blank

comments.text: +Battenburg70 And *that* is childish.
comments.author: HorseGirlb blank

comments.text:
+Battenburg70 Because it is a biological process that cannot be directly 
controlled. You can increase or decrease the chances of it happening, but 
you are not obligated to do so by law. Having sex is a freedom and cannot 
be punished by the government just because it is against your personal 
moral code.
comments.author: HorseGirlb blank

comments.text:
+Monica k The reason I got a problem with that is because that olive branch 
only extends so far it takes 2 to get pregnant, but it only take 1 to have 
the baby.
comments.author: Assassin55555

comments.text:
+kisamehoshigaki09 If I may point out: No one can control what they feel. 
They can try, question is if they'll be successful. If the woman had the 
child by her own decision, pressure from society or not, she definitely is 
responsible for that child, but if she's been pressured from society I'd 
think it's best to send her to counselling/therapy or such a thing to cope 
with her choice without letting it out on the child.
But still, it's not like she can control her feelings(Postnatal depression, 
for example), and I would not blame her for hating the child in the end. 
That does not necessarily mean that she would act out on the child, though 
of course therapy for both should be mandatory in that case, and the proper 
communication methods should be taught, so that both mother and child learn 
how to live with the problem.

And I am with you on mandatory organ donation after death.
comments.author: TheYasmineFlower

comments.text:
+HorseGirlb blank I'm not making a medical decision for anybody. I am 
making the assertion that if a woman decides not to have an abortion and 
has a child, they are responsible to care for and love that child. If they 
grow to 'hate' that child or blame it for their own personal problems they 
are immoral people who are at minimum psychologically abusing their 
children. I don't even know what you're talking about in regards to organ 
donation as it is irrelevant, but if you want my opinion I would in fact 
support mandatory organ donations provided they did not inhibit ones 
quality of life. No kidney, blood, marrow or liver donations required 
during life but all organs after death. Sure, why the fuck not?
comments.author: kisamehoshigaki09

comments.text:
+kisamehoshigaki09 What gives you the excuse to "be a horrible human being" 
and make medical decisions for other people's bodies? Violate their 
privacy, their bodies?

There are many violations of people's right to their own bodies that are 
considered unthinkably horrible. Assault & battery, murder, and rape are 
among the most common. But there are infinite scenarios that could be 
imagined. If it saved human lives, would you be in favor of mandatory organ 
donation, as opposed to voluntary? This means that you personally would be 
regularly subjected to blood draws and even bone marrow, as well as possess 
only one kidney and possibly sacrifice lobes of your liver. Would you 
support mandatory participation in experimental drug tests to produce 
life-saving medications?
comments.author: HorseGirlb blank

comments.text:

their responsibility.

comments.text: And it's also not just the mothers fault. What about the father?!?

controlled.

top_comment.text:
This is madness.
I'm 28 and have been married to my husband for 2 years (been together for 6 
years). I told him from the moment that our relationship became serious 
that children would be a deal breaker but happily we are on the same page. 
No plans for kids now or ever. :)
I decided around high school in my mid-late teens that I didn't want to 
have children. It's difficult to proclaim you decision let alone stand 
behind it when everyone is undermining your choice not to have them with 
such phrases as, "Oh you'll change your mind", "Oh you're young, you have 
plenty of time", "Wait til you get older, you will regret it". It makes you 
wonder, will I regret not having kids? Am I really missing out?
Much of society expects a person to go to school, get a job, get married, 
have kids. I wrestled with this because of society's (and my small town's) 
view being the expectation to have kids and if you don't then that must 
mean: you are a selfish person who will be lonely with no one to take care 
of you.
It drives me crazy when people say such awful things that are actually much 
more selfish. People are proclaiming you are selfish when you do not want 
to reproduce. That never made sense to me. Isn't it more selfish to have 
children for retirement or to combat loneliness?  If they're afraid of 
being lonely or that they need someone to take care of them when they're 
old then maybe they should be producing better retirement plans vs possible 
retirement child. There's never a guarantee that your needs will be met by 
your children (nor should that be asked of them) and if those are your 
reasons for having children (having a care taker and to have company) then 
you shouldn't be having any.
If you do want to have a child then you give them everything you can and 
the best of everything. It's about them now, many parts about you are put 
aside. You're doing this to have someone to share your love, watch them 
grow, share traditions and want the best for them. It's not right to expect 
anything in return. That is not the reason you brought this child into this 
world and this is a burden that shouldn't be expected of your child.
I for one, do not like children. I find them annoying, time consuming, 
dirty, loud, expensive, rude, greedy, exhausting, and sure, they're kids! 
That's normal! What do you expect? I don't want the responsibility or the 
commitment because I just know the pros do not outweigh the cons when it 
comes to me having a child. I don't want my body destroyed just so I can 
bring a mini-me into the world. I have enough anxiety issues as it is. I 
love my friends kids because I know them but only for short periods and I 
can decide when to come and go. I like my life. I like to spend my money, 
use my time and make plans based on myself and my husband. Not a kid. 
It's frustrating when people seem shocked or judge or ask why? First, how 
rude of you to ask! What if I can't have children? Thanks a lot for 
pointing that out. Secondly, what's it matter to you? Are you going to 
raise it? The annoyance and ignorance just continues. Children give your 
life meaning! No, children give YOUR life meaning. Why don't you want 
children? Um, why DO you want children? You don't know love til you have a 
child! I'm fine with that. I have the love of my husband, my friends, my 
parents, my furbabies and many others in my life to make me feel love and 
be loved. You'll want kids when you find the right man! Excuse me? My 
husband makes me plenty happy and vice versa, I don't need children to 
validate this. You're being selfish and you will regret it one day! Not 
likely. Women are meant to be mothers, the world depends on it! There are 7 
billion people on the planet, estimated 9 billion by the end of my 
generation. Mine won't be noticed, let alone missed. This day and age sure 
seems pretty scary to bring someone you love into the midst of it.
When asked "when or if" my husband and I are having children we simply say 
no. The backlash and the shock was hard to deal with but I'm working in a 
much bigger city where the majority of my coworkers seem to be more on my 
wave of thinking. I have the added benefit of having a husband who shares 
my ideals and my parents are not the type to be hounding for grandchildren. 
They think it is a marvelous decision and they agree that not having 
children can lead to a life that can be just as rewarding.
I lead a very happy and fulfilled life with my furbabies and my husband (we 
have 6 kitties and a greyhound), I am much more comfortable and confident 
in proclaiming my decision than I did in my early 20's. It is really no 
one's business and they should not question how I wish to lead my life. I 
choose to be child-free and I relish it.﻿
top_comment.author: megan ivy

comments.text:
+megan ivy I usually don't read such long You Tube comments, but you made 
so many intelligent and agreeable points that I had to finish reading it.
You've summed it all up. Only a fool or someone with a selfish agenda would

comments.author: MrFunnyGuy015

comments.text:
+mrnonsense1031 Haters gonna hate. It's good to know what you want in life, 
it's a rare thing. Some people just can't grasp a different opinion or want 
in life and others are just mad.
comments.author: megan ivy

comments.text:
I'm 22 and made a conscious decision to never have children and I wish I 
still got these normal replies: "You'll regret it when you're old" "You're 
missing out" "Kids give you meaning in life". Instead, I get death threats 
and conspiracy theories.
comments.author: MrFunnyGuy015

comments.text:
That's great to hear! It's difficult standing by what you know will make 
you happy when there's so many against your decision for various ridiculous 
reasons. Sometimes you got to trust your gut!
comments.author: megan ivy

comments.text:
You just basically told the story of my life! I feel the same as you. All 
of the things that people have said to you about having or not having 
children, I have heard a million times. As a child, I didn't play with baby 
dolls, I liked barbies. I loved playing as an independent, carefree woman 
with her own house, own car, and own life. I had no interest in pretending 
to be a mother. Obviously at 7, I didn't know what any of that meant, but 
in hindsight, I realize it was natural to me from the start. I don't want 
children. I never have. I never will. I get almost physically sick when 
people tell me "I'll change my mind" and "hurry before it's too late.". I 
think a lot of people with children have a secret resentment of people who 
don't have them. They envy your freedom, and try to guilt trip you by 
telling you you're selfish. I love that I can plan a spontaneous getaway 
without worrying about who will take the kids or worrying about them while 
I'm supposed to be relaxing on vacation. I love having a quiet house, with 
delicate glass, candles, and art. I love my huge perfume collection. I love 
making love anywhere in the house, any time of the day, without having to 
be quiet or have a "sex schedule". When I'm sick, I can stay in bed all day 
and *rest*. Those are just a few among so many other pros. I have lost out 
on some seriously nice guys because I don't want children. However, I have 
stood by my decision, and refused to give in. Yes, it has lead to some 
heartbreak, but I know what I want. Sometimes I do wonder if I will ever 
find a man who would be on the same page as me about this issue. I'm 30, 
and finding a guy who isn't a manwhore or ready to start a family is a 
challenge. I hope I can find someone who thinks as I do, and I'm really 
happy for you!
comments.author: DollnAbox

top_comment.text:
I'm 25, and I don't want to give birth to a child. I'm willing to adobt, 
hell I might want to adobt a child that is a bit older! This all came from 
me realising when I was a kid, that there are too many of us on this earth. 
There are so many of us, that a lot of children are put up for adobtion. So 
why should I be selfish and give birth to a child, when there are so many 
children out there that would love to have parents, who would love to have 
a stable home? Well, according to my friends, I'm being selfish, I don't 
know what I'm saying, I will change my mind, I'm just scared of giving 
birth (but its OK, with modern science the chanses of you dying are 
small!), having a child that is my flesh and blood will make all the 
difference! Well I feel sorry for you, if you need that bundle of nerves, 
flesh and blood to have your DNA for you to love them.﻿
top_comment.author: Bones McCoy
